newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chip stocks post strongest rally in three weeks.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chip stocks post strongest rally in three weeks.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks moved solidly higher Monday, posting their strongest rally in three weeks on better-than-expected earnings reports from several pacesetting companies.

The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 60.21 points at 6,451.90, its largest gain since a 101-point surge on March 24. Last week, the market was in a bearish mood as it fell nearly 135 points on interest rate worries.
In the broader market, declining issues still led advances 1,425 to 1,037 on moderate volume of 406 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

Analysts said nervous investors found some relief when a series of leading multinational companies, including Coca-Cola Co. and General Motors Corp., announced first-quarter profits that exceeded Wall Street's estimates.
"Today's rally suggests select stocks with good earnings may put some bounce back in the market," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Co.
Analysts cautioned, however, that market sentiment remained guarded, particularly with key inflation data due in Tuesday's Consumer Price Index.

"In general, results are coming in better than expected, but we've still got a test tomorrow in the CPI," said Charles White, managing director at Avatar Associates. "Today certainly doesn't mean we're out of the woods."
The looming report on inflation at the retail level held the bond market in check. The Treasury's 30-year bond was flat and its yield held at Friday's close of 7.17 percent.
The quiet bond market left stock traders free to focus on the generally favourable earnings news.
Stocks were rattled Friday by news that wholesale prices in March chalked up an unexpected 0.4 percent rise in the so-called core rate, which excludes often-volatile food and energy costs.
In addition to Coke, which rallied 2 to 55-3/4, and GM, which gained 1/2 to 53-1/2, Travelers Inc. also produced a favourable earnings surprise and climbed 2 to 48-3/8.
Analysts said the results provided a much-needed psychological boost for beleaguered investors, who had watched the Dow dive nearly 10 percent over the last five weeks.
"This market has been groping for a near-term bottom," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. "It looks like we may have found one."
"But there are definitely people still sitting this out," he said. "I expect this market to remain extremely choppy."

Investors got more favourable news after the close when Intel Corp. said its first-quarter profits more than doubled to $1.98 billion from $894 million in the same period last year. The per-share earnings of $2.20 per share beat analysts' estimates and hit a so-called "whisper number" that had been circulating around Wall Street.
Intel jumped to 135 in after-hours trading after a regular session that lifted the shares 3-1/4 to 133-1/4.
"Intel's number is an important one for the psychology of the market," Ackerman said, adding that the company was one of a handful that set the tone for technology shares.

Technology stocks generally turned in a solid performance, but one notable exception was Novellus Systems Inc., which tumbled 22-1/4 to 53 after the company announced it had lost a patent infringement trial. Novellus also reported first quarter earnings that were down sharply from a year ago.
Among other issues, Shaw Group Inc. slid 8-5/8 to 13 after warning of weak third and fourth quarter earnings.
Container carrier APL Ltd. jumped 8-1/4 to 29-3/4 after agreeing to be acquired by Singapore shipping firm Neptune Orient Lines Ltd. in a deal worth $825 million, or $33.50 per APL share.
The Nasdaq Composite index rose 9.51 points to 1,216.41.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 6.08 points to 743.73. The American Stock Exchange index fell 3.16 to 552.97.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 2.02 to 391.49. The average share was up 20 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,097.532 up 37.563 or 0.53 percent.
